Hammerclang Hero Review - Empires and Puzzles Strategy Guide

Hammerclang burst onto the scene as the Astral Elves' resident blacksmith, bringing a hammer that hits everyone and a debuff that makes enemies regret ever waking up. But with power creep moving faster than a mana troop on steroids, does this fiery forger still have the heat to compete in the current meta? Let's break it down.
Hammerclang: The Astral Blacksmith Who Never Misses a Beat (or a Hit)
Hammerclang: The Astral Blacksmith Forging Pain and Profit

Hammerclang is a 5-star Fire hero hailing from the glimmering Astral Elves family. Released back in March 2024, he quickly established himself as a titan specialist and a reliable damage dealer. His role is a hybrid of offensive support and direct damage dealing, functioning somewhat like a fiery, legendary version of a damage amplifier. While he doesn't bring the sheer destructive chaos of some modern "hit-all" nukes, his utility in softening up targets for the rest of your team is undeniable. He's the guy who loosens the jar lid so the rest of your team can open it—except the jar is an enemy team and "opening it" involves a lot of fire and explosions.

Visually, Hammerclang lives up to his name. He embodies the archetype of the celestial smith, sporting a look that blends high-fantasy elven elegance with the grit of a forge. He wields a hammer that looks like it could flatten a small moon and works on an anvil that glows with the heat of a thousand stars. The color palette is a vibrant mix of Astral Elf silvers and purples clashed against the fiery reds of his element and trade. It is a refreshing take on the "fire hero" trope, moving away from just "person on fire" to "person who works with fire."

When we look at Hammerclang's stats in the context of late 2025, the cracks in the anvil start to show. With a maximum Limit Broken (LB2) power of 1221, attack of 1267, and defense of 1297, he falls significantly behind the modern heavyweights like Devyani, who boasts stats pushing 1600 attack and 1500 defense.

In his prime, Hammerclang's stats were respectable, leaning towards a balanced distribution. Today, they are considered average to slightly low for a top-tier legendary. He isn't made of glass, but he certainly isn't the tanky fortress that newer heroes are. To keep him alive in the current meta of 3000+ HP monsters, you will need to invest heavily in emblems and limit breaks, and even then, he is more of a glass cannon than a frontline bruiser.
is a skill that ages better than the hero's stats. It does three distinct things very well:
This is a crucial utility against dodge-heavy metas. Whether it is rogue talents or dodge buffs, Hammerclang ignores them completely.
He deals a solid 400% to the target and minor damage to everyone else. It is effectively a "Hit-All" skill, though weighted heavily towards the primary target.

enemies is the crown jewel here. Unlike defense down, this stacks with regular defense down and elemental defense down, making it a key component in damage-maxing strategies, especially against Titans.
A -30% attack debuff on all enemies helps mitigating incoming damage, adding a layer of survivability to your team.
Fast. This means he charges in 8 tiles (7 with the right mana troop/talents). In Rush Attack wars or tournaments, he is blazing fast, but his native Fast speed makes him viable in almost any format.
400% damage. With his ~1267 attack (LB2), that is a raw damage output of roughly 5,068 (before defense calculation).
Minor damage usually equates to half the primary percentage, so roughly 200%. That is ~2,534 raw damage to four other enemies.

The +30% damage received is massive. If your sniper normally hits for 1000, they now hit for 1300. Across an entire team's special skills and tile damage, this adds up to thousands of extra damage points over 3 turns.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
Hammerclang benefits from the Astral Elves' lineage, which typically focuses on disruption and survivability.

The Astral Elves family bonus generally involves a chance to dispel the latest dispellable status ailment from the hero at the start of the turn, or a chance to resist mana reduction. While the specific bonus isn't the highlight compared to his special, being part of this family allows for synergy with other strong elves like Sparklight or Lemonwood.
A niche but welcome immunity. It helps against specific DoT heavy heroes, keeping his health pool cleaner.

He shares 20% of received damage with allies. This is a double-edged sword. It effectively gives him damage reduction, keeping him alive longer, but it spreads that pain to his teammates. In a team of squishy heroes, this can be dangerous, but if paired with tanky healers, it is excellent for his survival.
This passive adds a raw percentage increase to his special skill damage. For a damage dealer, this is the best Aether Power you could ask for, helping to close the gap created by power creep.
Upon release, Hammerclang was hailed as a "Titan Hard Hitter." The ability to increase damage taken by 30% on
enemies at Fast speed was a game-changer for high scores. He was often compared to heroes like Buster or Franz, but with the advantage of 5-star stats (at the time) and Fast mana.

Fast forward to late 2025, and Hammerclang's stats are undeniably dusty. Modern snipers deal 500-600% damage with stats that are 30-40% higher. His direct damage output is no longer threatening to top-tier defenses. However, his
remains top-tier. The "increase damage taken" debuff is a multiplier that scales with your
heroes. As your other heroes get stronger, Hammerclang makes them even stronger.
He has fallen out of the top meta. He is too squishy for top 100 defenses and lacks the one-shot potential for premier offense. However, he is still very usable in mid-tier wars and tournaments.
He remains a staple. The damage amplification is irreplaceable for many players.
Still excellent for speed-clearing waves due to the damage amp.
Hammerclang is a Rogue. This class is fantastic for him as the
talent significantly boosts his survivability, which is his main weak point today.
Maximizes his tile damage and special skill impact against Titans, which is his primary modern use case.
Keeps him alive longer to fire his debuff more than once in raids.
Sacrifices the tile damage needed for high scores.
path is recommended. You are likely bringing Hammerclang to amplify damage; you want his tiles to hurt, and you want his initial hit to sting. Rely on the Rogue evade talent for survival.
enemies is a rare and powerful debuff that scales well.
A hard counter to Dodge heroes (C. Kadilen, Bastet, etc.).
Charges quickly, allowing him to set the table for slower, harder hitters.
The -30% attack down is a solid survival tool for the whole team.
His stats are significantly lower than the late 2025 standard, making him vulnerable to one-shots.
Can accidentally kill low-health allies if he takes a massive hit (like a sniper shot).
The "minor damage" to nearby enemies is negligible against modern defense stats.
This is his home. The damage increase debuff is essential for pushing high scores.
Fast speed + damage amp helps clear mob waves and bosses quickly.
His speed and buffs/debuffs play well here.
Useful as a setup man for a red stack, specifically to counter dodge teams.
The key to using Hammerclang is to treat him as a
Hammerclang -> Guardian Falcon (or C. Marjana) -> Boldtusk -> Hard Hitting Sniper -> Tile Booster.
Hammerclang applies the damage taken increase. Falcon/Marjana applies Elemental Defense Down. Boldtusk applies Attack Up. The result is exponential damage on tiles and specials.
Use Hammerclang to bypass the dodge buffs on the enemy team and apply the damage amp. Follow up with your main heavy hitter to wipe the board.
Heroes who block status ailments (Garnet, Grazul) or reflect Red damage completely shut him down. Cleansers (Rigard, etc.) can wipe his precious debuff instantly.
Be careful pairing him with other "Damage Share" heroes unless you really know what you are doing, as the damage math can get weird and deadly for your own team.

If you pulled Hammerclang early, celebrate! He is a versatile carry. Focus on leveling him to unlock his special skill. He will be your best friend against map bosses and in raids. Don't worry too much about his stats being "outdated"—for a new player, he is a powerhouse.

You likely have heroes with better stats. Hammerclang's main value to you is on Mythic Titans, Alliance Titans, and perhaps specialized event teams. He is worthy of emblems if you use him for Titans, but think twice before using Alpha Aethers (LB2) unless you are chasing top 100 event scores or heavy titan damage. There are better recipients for those precious aethers in the 2025 meta.
The community has always had a soft spot for the "Blacksmith."
There was a significant debate upon release between Hammerclang and
. While Sparklight was generally seen as the better raw damage dealer, Hammerclang fans argued that his
Veterans recall that his beta version was different, and the change to "Fast" speed and "Damage Amp to All" saved him from mediocrity.
"He’s useful for titans, and I think only for titans," said one forum user. While harsh, this sentiment has aged to be largely true for endgame players.

Hammerclang is the workman of the Astral Elves. He doesn't have the flashiest animation or the biggest damage number, but he brings the tools that make everyone else look good. While the relentless march of power creep has dulled his edge in PvP, his hammer still rings true against Titans and in events. He is a hero with a clear purpose, and he fulfills it with Fast efficiency.
Is he worth the mats? For Titans alone, yes. Just don't expect him to tank shots from the gods of 2025 without feeling the heat.
A retired PvP gladiator who found a lucrative second career as a Titan specialist. Keep him for the big beasts.
Is Hammerclang still the king of the forge in Empires and Puzzles? We analyze his stats, special skill, and viability in the current meta in this detailed review.
